119378 S0926-860X(23)00358-7 10.1016/j.apcata.2023.119378 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns of (a) synthesized CoxAl precursors with different Co/Al molar ratios and (b) Pt/CoxAl-y samples. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM images of Pt/Co2Al-700 (Insert: HR-TEM images). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) Catalytic results of various Pt/CoxAl-y catalysts for APR of methanol (reaction conditions: 100 mg of catalyst, 15 mL aqueous methanol solution (n(CH3OH):n(H2O) = 1:3), 2 MPa N2, 220 ºC, 1 h); (b) Approaching “real” methanol APR results of Pt/Co2Al-700 (reaction conditions for the first cycle: 50 mg of catalyst, 2 MPa N2, 15 mL aqueous methanol solution (n(CH3OH):n(H2O) = 1:3), 220 ºC, 1 h). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XRD patterns of fresh (a) and reduced (b) Pt/Co2Al-700 and used analogues for one (c) and 10 cycles (d). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of (a) Pt/CoxAl-700 and (b) Pt/Co2Al-y (the black dotted line represents the H2-TPR profiles of parent CoxAl-y), and deconvolved H2-TPR profiles of (c) Pt/CoxAl-700 and (d) Pt/Co2Al-y. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 In-situ CO adsorption DRIFTS of Pt/Al2O3, Pt/Co3O4, Co2Al-700, and Pt/ Co2Al-700 at (a) 30 ºC and (b) 220 ºC. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Co 2p (a, b) and O 1 s (c, d) XPS of (a, c) Pt/CoxAl-700 and (b, d) Pt/Co2Al-y. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The relative oxygen vacancy contents of Pt/CoxAl-y samples (a) and the EPR measurement results of the tested samples (b). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (a) Co 2p, (b) O 1 s, and (c) Pt 4d XPS of reduced Co2Al-700, reduced Pt/Co2Al-700, and its counterparts after one and ten cycles. A series of CoAl oxide-supported Pt catalysts (Pt/CoxAl, x = Co/Al ratio) was developed for aqueous-phase reforming of methanol to H2. CoxAl oxides were prepared by calcining layered double hydroxides at different temperatures. The catalytic performance of Pt/CoxAl highly depends on the Co/Al ratio and the calcination temperature. The most active Pt/Co2Al catalyst calcined at 700 °C showed an H2 production rate of 3372 µmolH2·g−1 catalyst·min−1 with low CO selectivity. The intense interaction between Pt and support and abundant oxygen vacancies results in high catalytic performance. Intensive characterization and mechanism study reveal that both Pt0 and metallic Co0 promote methanol decomposition. At the same time, H2O is activated on the support and reacts with CO to generate intermediate formate species that are further converted into CO2 and H2. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Methanol Aqueous-phase reforming Hydrogen spillover CoAl oxide Pt Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to the massive consumption of fossil fuels and increasing environmental pollution, sustainable development is gaining widespread attention. Therefore, it is a looming issue to figure out an alternative to traditional energy. Hydrogen is considered one of the most promising candidates because of its attractive properties, such as high energy density and clean emissions [1,2]. However, concerns regarding the security of transportation and storage have hindered its large-scale application. Moreover, industrial hydrogen production is still dominated by unsustainable ways such as natural gas and oil reforming [3]. Therefore, finding suitable hydrogen carriers and renewable hydrogen sources has become an urgent task. Methanol has several obvious advantages, such as a liquid at room temperature, high H/C ratio, low conversion temperature, and affordability, making it an ideal choice for storing H2 [4,5]. It can be converted into hydrogen through steam reforming (SR) or aqueous phase reforming (APR) [6–8], which is somehow considered a renewable and sustainable way, as methanol can be produced from biomass [9,10]. Compared to steam reforming, APR allows operation at lower temperatures and avoids cumbersome and energy-consuming vaporization units [11,12], which makes it suitable for portable systems such as hydrogen vehicles. Furthermore, due to the thermodynamic feasibility of the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction under APR conditions, the H2 produced from APR is purer and contains less CO. This benefit favors catalytic stability and facilitates the utilization of generated H2 in fuel cells [13]. Ru, Pd, Ni, and Pt are active metals generally used for the APR process [14–17]. Ru shows higher utilization efficiency in homogeneous reactions [18]. However, the intrinsic drawbacks of a homogeneous catalytic system limit its industrial application. More severely, adding alkaline substances causes environmental pollution. Thus, much attention has been paid to the development of heterogeneous catalysts. In this aspect, Ni-based catalysts exhibit superior activity but generate more small molecule-sized alkanes [17,19], despite that a Ni/α-MoC catalyst with a high density of isolated Ni atoms gave an average turnover frequency (ATOF) of 1800 h−1 at 240 ºC [20]. Compared with Pd-based catalysts, Pt shows higher activity [17]. Therefore, various Pt-based catalysts have been prepared and used for the APR of methanol [21–25]. A typical catalyst is Pt/α-MoC with ATOF as high as 18,046 h−1 [23]. This excellent activity originates from the synergistic effect between Pt and α-MoC, where atomically dispersed, high-density electron-deficient Pt particles serve for adsorption or activation of methanol, while α-MoC facilitates water dissociation. Introducing a second component, such as Ru [26], Mo, Fe [27], and Co [28], results in improved catalytic properties of Pt. It has been shown that PtCo bimetallic catalysts are highly active for both APR and WGS reactions [29–31]. The APR performance of Pt-based catalysts is closely related to the support structure and could be improved by increasing basic strength [32,33]. However, the inferior hydrothermal stability of basic supports limits their application. γ-Al2O3 is a classical support due to its high stability. However, its acidity may be detrimental to the APR performance [12], and its water resistance is insufficient [34]. Therefore, finding stable support with high APR activity remains a challenge. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are a large family of two-dimensional anionic clay materials with tunable capacities of metal cations, M2+/M3+ molar ratios, and interlayer compensating anions [35]. Mixed metal oxides obtained from LDHs by controlled thermal decomposition have attracted great research interests because of their large specific surface areas, basic properties, uniform and thermally stable dispersion of metal species, and the synergistic effect among different components [36]. Furthermore, their strong adsorption capacity makes them serve as adequate support. LDHs and their derived catalysts have been widely used in the SR and APR processes of various oxygenated organic compounds like methanol, ethanol, glycerol, etc. [8,37–39]. For instance, He et al. developed a series of Co-Ni LDHs-derived catalysts that showed high activity and stability during ethanol steam reforming [40]. In the APR of ethanol and glycerol, LDHs derived Ni and Ni-Cu catalysts exhibited good performance with long time activity [41]. Pt-supported mixed oxides derived from MgAl LDHs achieved 67.4 % H2 selectivity in glycerol APR and remained active after four reusability tests [42]. Here, CoAl-LDHs with tunable Co/Al ratios were prepared and thermally decomposed to fabricate a high-performance methanol APR catalyst through anchoring Pt species. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of CO-adsorption, and H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) results reveal that the catalytic activity of Pt/CoAl oxide is closely related to its support surface oxygen vacancy concentration, and can be enhanced by the synergistic interaction between Pt and support. In situ DRIFTS and temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) results indicate that the reaction occurs via a tandem process of methanol decomposition and subsequent WGS reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Co(NO3)2·6 H2O (≥ 98.5 %) and Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (≥ 99.0 %) were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Methanol (≥ 99.5 %), Na2CO3 (≥ 99.8 %), and NaOH (≥ 99.0 %) were purchased from Kermel Co. Ltd. (Tianjin, China). H2PtCl6·6 H2O (ACS, Pt ≥ 37.5 %), γ-Al2O3 (≥ 99.9 %, 20 nm), and CoO (AR) were acquired from Aladdin Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All the reagents are used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation CoAl-LDHs were synthesized by the reported co-precipitation method [43–45]. An aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2·6 H2O and Al(NO3)3·9 H2O with a designed molar ratio (CoAl = 1, 2 or 3) was labeled as solution A, and that of Na2CO3 and NaOH was marked as solution B. The metal concentration in solution A was 1 mol/L, and the molar ratio of CO3 2-/Al3+ in solution B was controlled to 2. Solution A and B were dropwise added into a beaker by peristaltic pumps at room temperature under vigorous agitation, with the pH value kept at 9.5 ± 0.5. The obtained slurry was aged 65 ºC for 18 h under mild stirring conditions. The resultant precipitate was filtered and washed several times with deionized water until the pH was 7. After drying at 80 ºC, the deposit was ground into fine powders and calcined at the target temperature for 4 h. The obtained CoAl oxides were designated as CoxAl-y, with x and y representing Co/Al molar ratio and calcination temperature, respectively. For comparison, CoAl2O4 was prepared by adjusting the Co/Al molar ratio to 1/2 and setting the calcination temperature to 800 ºC. Pt/CoxAl-y was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method. Typically, 400 mg CoxAl-y was added in a beaker containing 529 mg aqueous chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6·6 H2O, 37.5 mmol/L), corresponding to 1 wt% Pt. After sonication of 10 min, the obtained material was statically kept for 8 h at room temperature. Then, it was dried at 80 ºC in a vacuum oven for 12 h. After being fully ground, it was calcined at 300 ºC in the air. Other Pt-based catalysts were prepared similarly, with CoO, Al2O3, and Co3O4 as support. Co3O4 was prepared by a common co-precipitation method [46]. Firstly, 1.5 g Co(NO3)2·6 H2O was dissolved in 20 mL deionized water, followed by dropwise adding 100 mL Na2CO3 solution (0.5 mol/L) at ambient temperature for 1 h. After stirring for another 1 h, the mixture was separated by centrifugation and washed with deionized water several times. The precipitate was dried at 100 ºC for 24 h and calcined at 400 ºC for 6 h to obtain Co3O4. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Bruker D8 Advance A25 diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source. Each sample was scanned from 5 to 80º (2θ) at a scanning rate of 4º/min. The crystallite size was estimated by the Scherrer equation. In situ XRD experiments were conducted on another Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer. All patterns were recorded after reduction at the designed temperature in a 10 % H2/Ar flow (60 mL min−1) for 1 h. Metal contents in prepared catalysts and reaction solutions were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Thermo iCAP6300). Before the measurement, solid samples were dissolved in aqua regia (HCl/HNO3 = 3/1, volume ratio) for 24 h at 100 ºC. Diffuse reflectance ultraviolet–visible (DR UV-Vis) spectra were taken on an Agilent Cary 5000 UV–vis–NIR spectrophotometer with an integrating sphere with BaSO4 as a reference sample. The spectra were recorded from 200 to 800 nm at a scanning rate of 600 nm/min. N2 physisorption isotherms were measured on a Tristar II 3020 volumetric adsorption analyzer. Prior to the measurement, the sample was pretreated at 300 ºC for 8 h under a high vacuum. The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken on a JEM 2010 microscope (JEOL). Average Pt particle size was calculated by the following equations：. d TEM = Σn i d i 3/Σn i d i 2 where n i is the number of particles with a diameter of d i . Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) of the samples was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. Approximately 50 mg of the sample was placed in a quartz tube and pretreated at 300 ºC for 2 h in an argon flow (30 mL min−1). After being cooled to room temperature, the quartz tube was heated to 800 ºC in a 10 % H2/Ar flow at a rate of 10 ºC/min, and hydrogen consumption was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). CO pulse chemisorption was also conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. Typically, 100 mg sample was pretreated at 300 ºC for 2 h in a stream of H2 (30 mL min−1). Then, the sample was subsequently cooled to 50 ºC and purged with high-purity He flow (30 mL min−1). A series of CO pulses (1.341 mmol/min) was introduced into the quartz tube until the eluted peak area did not change. The stoichiometry factor for Pt/CO and the cross-sectional area of Pt were assumed to be 1/1 and 0.08 nm2, respectively. The amount of CO adsorbed on catalyst was determined by CO temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) technique performed on a Micromeritics Bel Cata II chemisorption analyzer. CO in the desorbed gas was monitored and quantified using a mass spectrometer (Bel Mass). XPS was recorded on an ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer (Thermo Fischer, USA) equipped with an Al Kα radiation source (hν = 1486.6 eV). Binding energies were calibrated by C 1 s peak (284.4 eV) of adventitious carbon as reference. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were monitored on a spectrometer (Bruker EMXPLUS) with 9.84 GHz X-band. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) of CO adsorption, methanol reforming, and methanol decomposition were collected on a Bruker VERTEX 80 v spectrometer equipped with an MCT detector. The sample was firstly in situ reduced at 300 ºC for 1 h in H2, then purged with Ar for another 1 h at 300 ºC. Later, the temperature was cooled to 30 ºC. In the CO adsorption experiment, 10 % CO/Ar was introduced in the cell and allowed to be adsorbed for 10 min. After that, the feed gas was switched to Ar, and the sample was purged for 1 h. Finally, CO adsorption spectra were recorded. The DRIFTS of CO adsorption at 220 ºC were carried out according to the same procedures. In the methanol reforming experiment, a methanol and water mixture was introduced into the cell by Ar bubbling. In situ DRIFTS were collected every minute for up to 15 min at the designed temperature. The spectra were also recorded after purging the sample for 15 min with Ar to exclude the effect of gaseous reactants and products. In situ DRIFTS for methanol adsorption was measured the same way as for methanol reforming. After collecting the spectra for methanol adsorption at 220 °C, H2O was introduced, and the spectra were recorded every minute for up to 15 min after purging the sample with Ar. In situ DRIFTS of WGS on Pt/Co2Al-700 was carried out at 220 ºC according to the same procedures with water introduced by bubbling with a 1 % CO/Ar gas flow (50 mL min−1). TPD experiment of methanol, water, CO, and CO2 was performed in a quartz reactor connected with a Hiden Analytical HPR-20 R&D mass spectrometer. The reactor was loaded with 50 mg of sample (40–60 mesh). After the sample was reduced at 300 °C for 2 h in pure H2, the system was purged with Ar at 300 °C for 30 min. Then, the reactor was cooled to 50 °C, and methanol or water was introduced by bubbling with Ar flow (30 mL min−1). After adsorption for 30 min, the system was flushed with the Ar flow until the signal was unchanged. Subsequently, the reactor was heated from 50 °C to 500 °C at a rate of 5 °C min−1, and desorbed profiles of CH3O (m/z = 31), water (m/z = 18), CO (m/z = 28) or CO2 (m/z = 44) were recorded. The signal of CH3O is recorded to distinguish CH3OH and O2. Temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) was carried out in a quartz tube with 50 mg of catalyst (40–60 mesh). After reduction at 300 °C for 2 h in pure H2, the system was purged with Ar for 30 min and then cooled to 50 °C. Then, a mixture of methanol and water was introduced into the reaction cell by bubbling with Ar flow (30 mL min−1). After the signal became steady, the system was heated to 400 °C at 3 °C min−1. The signals of H2 (m/z = 2), H2O (m/z = 18), CO (m/z = 28), CH3O (m/z = 31), Ar (m/z = 440), CO2 (m/z = 44), and HCOOH (m/z = 46) were detected by an OMNISTER mass spectrometer. 2.4 Catalytic tests APR of methanol was carried out in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Unless specified, the catalyst was reduced at 300 ºC for 2 h in a 10 % H2/Ar flow (60 mL min−1) before the reaction. 15 mL aqueous methanol solution (n(CH3OH): n(H2O) = 1:3) and 0.1 g catalyst were put into the autoclave, which was purged three times with 2 MPa N2 after being sealed. The reaction was carried out at 220 ºC for 1 h. It was terminated by swiftly cooling down the autoclave to room temperature. Gaseous products were collected in a gas bag and analyzed by a Shimadzu GC-2014 C gas chromatography equipped with a thermal conduction detector (TCD). Isopropanol was used as an internal standard to quantify methanol concentration in the liquid product. The catalytic performances of samples are evaluated by hydrogen production rate, expressed as the micromolar amount of H2 generated per gram of catalyst per minute. Turnover frequency (TOF) is defined as the moles of H2 produced per mole of Pt per hour. It is calculated based on the amount of exposed Pt measured by CO pulse chemisorption. Methanol conversion (C MeOH) and CO selectivity (S CO) were calculated by the following equation: C MeOH = (c MeOH, bef· - c MeOH, aft·)/ c MeOH, bef S CO = n CO/n H2 Where c MeOH, bef. and c MeOH, aft. represent methanol concentration before and after the reaction, while n CO and n H2 are the molar concentrations of CO and H2. Evaluation of approaching “real” methanol APR is meaningful because the initial activity is an essential indicator for applying such hydrogen production systems in vehicle fuel cells [20,23]. The evaluated results shown in Fig. 3b were obtained at 220 ºC. The reaction was performed for 1 h for each cycle, and the next run was carried out directly after releasing gaseous products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Fig. 1a shows that all the synthesized precursors with different Co/Al molar ratios are typical LDH phases with rhombohedral symmetric structures (PDF 51-0045) [47]. Nevertheless, the diffraction peaks shift to a lower 2θ degree with increasing Co content in the sample, indicative of incorporating more Co2+ ions, as Al3+ ion has a smaller ionic radius than Co2+ [48]. The average crystallite sizes of Co1Al-LDH, Co2Al-LDH, and Co3Al-LDH are 16.8, 25.3, and 14.9 nm, respectively. After calcination, the precursors are converted into CoAl spinel-like phases (Fig. S1) [49,50], and the crystallinity increases with Co amount and calcination temperature. Although the diffraction peaks of CoxAl3-xO4 (0 < x ≤ 2) and Co3O4 are identified, the exact structure of the prepared CoxAl-y oxide is difficult to be determined by XRD pattern only [51]. After adding Pt, there is a slight variation in the crystalline size of CoxAl-y (Table S1), but the position of diffraction peaks does not change noticeably (Fig. 1b). The absence of diffraction peaks of Pt species (Pt0 or its oxide) implies their high dispersion. The spinel lattice is characterized by a compact arrangement of cubic close-packed anions with divalent and trivalent cations occupying tetrahedral and octahedral sites [52]. Change of metal cation oxidation states affords many types of spinels [53]. Two typical cases are normal (e.g., CoAl2O4) and inverse spinel (e.g., Co2AlO4). Intermediate states between these two cases are formed when trivalent cations partially occupy the tetrahedral interstices. Thermal decomposition of CoAl-LDH (Co/Al = 3) at a temperature higher than 200 ºC generates spinel Co(Co, Al)2O4, viz. solid solutions of Co3O4, Co2AlO4, and CoAl2O4 [44,54]. Upon calcination at 500 ºC, CoAl-LDH structure was destructed to form a spinel cobalt solid solution. Elevating calcination temperature leads to incorporating specific numbers of amorphous Al species into the spinel structure [55], forming more Co2AlO4 that may be further transformed into CoAl2O4. Table S2 lists the textural properties and chemical compositions of Pt/CoxAl-y samples. As expected, the surface areas of these samples decrease with increasing calcination temperature and Al content. The surface area of Pt/Co2Al-700 is 41.5 m2/g. Compared with bulk Co/Al ratios, surface Co/Al ratios are smaller, suggesting that the catalyst surfaces are rich in Al. Fig. 2 and Fig. S2 show that CoxAl-y oxide particles have a plate-like habit and grow large with increasing calcination temperature, in agreement with XRD results. The average Pt particle size in Pt/Co2Al-700 is as small as 1.4 nm, while that of Pt/Co2Al-500 is too small to be discerned. Nevertheless, all the samples display small Pt nanoparticle (NP) sizes (Table S3, Fig. S3), revealing a high dispersion. The lattice spacings in high-resolution (HR) TEM images correspond to Pt (111) and spinel Co(Co, Al)2O4 (111) [56,57]. All the CoxAl-y samples exhibit similar absorption bands in DR UV-Vis spectra (Fig. S4). Broad band between 550 and 800 nm is attributed to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) from O2- to octahedral Co3+ species [58], while that in the region from 260 to 550 nm is assigned to the LMCT from O2- to tetrahedral Co2+ species. The absorption band at around 240 nm is due to the LMCT of O2- 2 to octahedral Co3+ species [59]. The UV-Vis spectroscopy reveals that all the CoxAl-y samples contain both Co3+ and Co2+ species. Three bands at 548, 589, and 631 nm in the spectrum of CoAl2O4 are characteristic of transitions of Co2+ electrons in 3d7 orbitals in tetrahedral coordination [58,60]. The absence of these bands in the range of CoxAl-y samples indicates that CoAl2O4 is not the primary phase in these samples. Compared to the absorption bands in the spectrum of Co3O4, a significant blue shift is observed for CoxAl-y oxides, and the degree is enhanced with increasing Al content and calcination temperature. This indicates that the octahedral Co3+ species progressively evolve into tetrahedral Co2+ species, and CoxAl-y intends to transform into CoAl2O4. It has been reported that pure Co2AlO4 and CoAl2O4 exhibit dark green and bright blue colors, respectively [55,60,61]. CoxAl-y oxides are deeply dark green and close to black. This, in combination with DR UV-Vis spectra, further corroborates that CoxAl-y is Co(Co, Al)2O4, which is gradually transformed into CoAl2O4 with increasing Al content and annealing temperature. In H2-TPR profiles (Fig. S5a), Co2Al-700 and Co3Al-700 show two broad peaks at 300 ∼ 500 ºC and 600 ∼ 700 ºC, while three intense peaks are present between 350 and 800 °C for Co1Al-700, implying that it contains more cobalt phases. The reduction peaks of CoxAl-y shift to lower temperatures with increasing Co content, indicative of weakened interaction between Co and Al species. Fig. S5b shows that Co2Al-y samples calcined below 700 ºC display two major reduction peaks around 400 and 660 ºC. In contrast, in addition to the above two peaks, another broad peak above 700 ºC is observed in the profiles of Co2Al-800 and Co2Al-900. Deconvolution of the broad peak in the region from 300 to 500 °C gives two components attributed to the reduction of Co3+ ions on the surface, and those interacted with Al, to Co2+, respectively [51,57,59] (Table S4). The peak between 600 and 700 ºC is due to the reduction of Co2+ to Co0 [60]. It seems that the reduction of Co2+ shifts to a lower temperature with increased calcination temperature, but reducing Co3+ to Co2+ becomes difficult, indicative of enhancing interaction between Co and Al species. A broad peak at around 740 and 765 ºC in the profiles of Co2Al-800 and Co2Al-900 implies that the CoAl2O4 spinel phase is formed in both samples [62] (Figs. S5b and S6). 3.2 Catalytic performance of Pt/CoxAl-y for APR of methanol Fig. 3a and Table 1 show the catalytic results for APR of methanol on Pt-based catalysts. Clearly, Pt/CoxAl-y samples were more active than Pt supported on CoAl2O4, CoO, and Al2O3, and their catalytic activity exhibited a volcanic relationship with calcination temperature and Co/Al ratio. The sample calcined at 700 °C with a Co/Al molar ratio of 2 exhibited higher activity than other Pt/CoxAl-y samples. It gave an H2 production rate of 3372 µmolH2·g−1 catalyst·min−1. As shown in Fig. S7, there are five components in the gaseous product: H2, N2, CO, CH3OH, and CO2. The catalytic performance of Pt/CoxAl-y can be further enhanced by optimizing its reduction temperature. Upon reduction at 600 °C for 2 h, the H2 production rate of Pt/Co2Al-700 can be increased to 5680 µmolH2·g−1 catalyst·min−1 (Table 1, entry 2). Notably, all samples produced a sole by-product of CO with much lower selectivity (≈ 0.3 %) than Pt/Co3O4 (1.04 %, Table 1, entry 10) and Pt/CoO (5.01 %, Table 1, entry 6). No CO was monitored on Pt/Al2O3 (Table 1, entry 8). Methanol conversion and TOF for these Pt/CoxAl-y catalysts are shown in Table S5. It can be seen that methanol conversion ranged from 6.3 % to 9.2 %, while the TOF values varied from 2570 h−1 to 4737 h−1. Co2Al-700 reduced at 300 ºC was nearly inactive, while those reduced at 500 and 700 °C showed a hydrogen production rate of 744 and 1388 µmolH2·g−1 catalyst·min−1 with CO selectivity of 1.86 % and 1.66 %, respectively (Table 1, entries 3–5). The reduction of Co ions to metallic Co0 was not observed below 450 ºC in the H2-TPR profile of Co2Al-700 (Fig. S5). Most Co species in Co2Al-700 are reduced to metallic Co0 at 800 ºC. This suggests that metallic Co is active for the APR of methanol. However, it can simultaneously catalyze reverse WGS reaction and methanol decomposition, which accounts for the increased CO selectivity on Pt/Co2Al-700 after reduction at 600 ºC. CoO and Al2O3 showed almost no activity (Table 1, entries 7 and 9), while Co3O4 reduced at 500 ºC exhibited an H2 production rate of 298 µmolH2·g−1 catalyst·min−1 (Table 1, entry 11). In contrast, the hydrogen production rate over a reduced physical mixture of Pt/Co3O4 and Pt/Al2O3 at 300 °C achieved 2038 µmolH2·g−1 catalyst·min−1 with CO selectivity of only 0.37 % (Table 1, entry 12). This demonstrates that Pt NPs play a vivid role in the APR of methanol. Methanol reaction on Pt/Co2Al-700 under the same conditions gave an H2 production rate of 2516 µmolH2·g−1 catalyst·min−1 but with CO selectivity as high as 42.74 % (Table 1, entry 13), consolidating that APR of methanol indeed occurs when water is present. The H2 production rate of Pt/Co2Al-700 ranged between 3034 and 4122 µmolH2·g−1 catalyst·min−1 over ten cycles, with a slight decrease in catalytic performance (Fig. 3b). Notably, the H2 production rate was enhanced after the first run, and CO selectivity gradually decreased with the reaction cycles. TEM images of the used Pt/Co2Al-700 indicate that the morphology of Pt/Co2Al-700 is maintained after repeated cycles (Fig. S8), and its Pt dispersion is improved in the reaction process, as evidenced by unobserving Pt NPs. This may lead to enhanced catalytic performance after the first run. Table S6 shows that the chemical compositions of fresh and used catalysts are similar. The same contents of Pt and Al confirm no leaching of these two elements. A slight Co/Al ratio decrease implies that Co species leaching is not severe. Nevertheless, filtrate colors are different after the reaction on Pt/Co2Al-y catalysts (Fig. S9). Pt/Co2Al-700 catalytic system filtrate is nearly colorless, while the others exhibit green or blue. This demonstrates that Pt/Co2Al-700 has higher stability than the other Pt/Co2Al-y samples. 3.3 Structure-catalytic performance relationship of Pt/CoxAl-y The XRD patterns of fresh, reduced, and used Pt/Co2Al-700 are displayed in Fig. 4. Compared to fresh Pt/Co2Al-700, the reduced sample shows three major peaks at 2θ of 37.0º, 43.1º, and 62.6º, which are slightly higher than those of CoO (PDF 43-1719), indicating the formation of Co(Al)O solid solution [57]. A small peak at about 31.3º is attributed to a spinel-like phase. After one reaction run, the diffraction peaks indexed to hcp and fcc Co0 species (PDF 05-0727 and PDF 15-0806) appear at 41.7º, 44.4º, 47.4º, and 75.9º. Therefore, H2 produced from APR reduces Co species and improves catalytic performance. In addition, the Co3O4-like phase is identified. It is formed through the disproportionation of CoO in the reaction process, leading to reduced hydrogen production activity in the cycling test (Fig. 3b). Nonetheless, the diffraction peaks of Pt0 at 39.8º, 46.2º, and 67.5º are not observed yet. It needs to point out that the diffraction peaks of Co0 are barely resolved, either, after ten cycles, which accounts well for the lower H2 production rate at the 10th run than at the 2nd run. Fig. 5 shows that all the Pt/CoxAl-y samples have 3 ∼ 4 reduction peaks. The small peak in the 140–160 ºC range is ascribed to the reduction of PtOx to Pt0. Peaks corresponding to the reduction of Co3+ and Co2+ attached on the surface and interacted with Al species shift to lower temperature by > 100 °C, compared to parent CoxAl-y. This shows that the impregnation of Pt on CoxAl-y significantly facilitates its reduction due to the spillover effect of H* dissociated by Pt [36,63]. Irrespective of this, the promotion degree highly depends on the Co/Al ratio and the calcination temperature of CoxAl-y (Fig. 5c and d). Pt/Co2Al-700, followed by Pt/Co2Al-600, exhibits the most severe decline in the reduction temperature (by more than 200 °C) (Table S4, entry 4). Moreover, both samples show the most extensive reduction degree (Fig. 5a and b). The peak above 700 ºC is attributed to the reduction of Co2+ in CoAl2O4 to Co0. It is much more difficult to be promoted by the hydrogen spillover effect. The in situ XRD patterns of Co2Al-700 and its supported Pt analogue are similar at 30 ºC (Figs. S10a and b). However, a CoO-like phase is formed on Pt/Co2Al-700 after reduction at 300 ºC, but it was not detected in the reduced Co2Al-700. A further increase of reduction temperature to 500 ºC leads to the formation of metallic Co0 on Pt/Co2Al-700 at the expense of the CoO-like phase, and the amount increases with the reduction temperature. In contrast, no appreciable amounts of Co0 were observed in Co2Al-700 even when it was reduced at 600 ºC. This further substantiates the hydrogen spillover effect of Pt species. Fig. 6a shows CO adsorption spectra on reduced Pt/Co2Al-700, and for comparison, on reduced Pt/Al2O3, Pt/Co3O4, and Co2Al-700 at 30 ºC. No evident vibration bands were detected in the ν(CO) stretching frequency region in the spectrum of Co2Al-700. Two weak vibrational bands at 2360 and 2340 cm−1 are associated with the formation of CO2. The difficultly resolved bands at 1200–1700 cm−1 are assigned to adsorbed carbonate species. Pt/Co3O4 shows only CO2 bands, suggesting that CO is probably oxidized by incompletely reduced cobalt ions. Pt/Al2O3 possesses a broad band at around 2061 cm−1 and a small band at 1815 cm−1, which arise from linear and bridged CO adsorptions on metallic Pt0 species, respectively [64,65]. In contrast, Pt/Co2Al-700 displays at least six bands. In addition to the linear and bridged CO adsorptions on metallic Pt0 sites, a weak band due to linear adsorption of CO on Pt-interfered Co sites is resolved at 2007 cm−1 [66,67]. Another band around 1773 cm−1 is assigned to 3-fold CO adsorption on Pt sites [68,69]. The appearance of carbonate species at 1488 and 1394 cm−1 implies that Co species in Co(Al)O solid solution could be partially reduced by CO. Since the APR of methanol is carried out at 220 ºC, and CO may be an essential intermediate, in situ CO adsorption DRIFTS at 220 ºC is also measured (Fig. 6b). Compared to CO adsorption at 30 °C, the bands of bridge-adsorbed CO disappeared in the spectra of Pt/Co2Al-700 and Pt/Al2O3, while those of CO2 and formate species were observed at 2361, 2338, 1590, 1392, and 1374 cm−1. In addition, that attributed to CO adsorbed on the Pt-interfered Co sites shifted to 2036 cm−1 [70]. Pt/Co2Al-700 shows much more intense features in the region from 1600 to 1300 cm−1, indicative of the formation of more mono- and bidentate carbonates or formate species [71]. Formate species are important intermediates in the WGS reaction process. It may be formed by the reaction of adsorbed CO with OH groups on the support surface, which is supported by observing three bands at 3734 cm−1, 3664 cm−1, and 3559 cm−1 in the spectrum of Co2Al-700 (Fig. S11). This suggests that Pt0 species are the main sites for CO adsorption since the CO adsorption bands are not observed in the spectrum of Co2Al-700. The amount of CO adsorbed on Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Co2Al-700 was quantified using the CO-TPD technique. As shown in Fig. S12, Pt/Co2Al-700 adsorbed more CO (0.163 mmol/g) than Pt/Al2O3 (0.067 mmol/g). Fig. 7 shows the Co 2p and O 1 s XPS of Pt/CoxAl-y samples, and corresponding fitting results are listed in Table S7. All the Co 2p3/2 spectra were deconvolved into five components. The binding energy of Co0 in Pt/CoxAl-y centers between 777.6 and 778.0 eV [72], while those of Co3+ and Co2+ are in the ranges of 779.7–779.8 eV and 780.6–782.4 eV, respectively [73]. A peak at 786.0 eV is the shake-up satellite signal [60]. Co 2p XPS reveals the co-existence of Co3+, Co2+, and Co0 species in the reduced sample. Pt/Co2Al-700 contains more Co0 species than other Pt/CoxAl-y samples (Table S7, entry 4). The most potent hydrogen spillover effect of Pt on Co species in Pt/Co2Al-700 promotes the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ species and further to Co0. Deconvolution of broad O 1 s peak shows the presence of lattice oxygen species (Oα), oxygen vacancies (Oβ), and adsorbed OH groups (Oγ) (Fig. 7c and d) [73,74]. Generally, the oxygen species around 531.1 eV (Oβ) result from the oxygen molecules adsorbed on oxygen vacancies, whose content on the surface directly reflects the concentration of oxygen vacancies [75]. The relative oxygen vacancy content of Pt/CoxAl-y samples exhibits a volcanic relationship with calcination temperature and Co/Al ratio, and Pt/Co2Al-700 has the highest content ( Fig. 8a and Table S7). Oxygen vacancies are reported to promote not only the dissociative adsorption of methanol but also facilitate the dissociation of H2O, both of which are crucial processes in the APR of methanol [30,74]. Therefore, EPR measurements were conducted to further verify the existence of oxygen vacancies (Fig. 8b). Typical axial signals of the electrons trapped by oxygen vacancies are observed in the spectra of all detected samples, with g values around 2.002. The inherent magnetism of the sample makes signal resolution poor. Hence, the fitted profiles of EPR results are illustrated in Fig. S13. Compared to other catalysts, Pt/Co2Al-700 exhibits enhanced signal intensity owing to more oxygen vacancies, which is consistent with the quantitative results of O 1 s XPS. Fig. 9 shows the XPS of reduced Co2Al-700, reduced Pt/Co2Al-700, and its counterparts used for one and ten cycles. Table 2 summarizes the corresponding simulation results. Reduced Co2Al-700 contains 10.5 % of Co0 species (Table 2, entry 1). Loading of Pt lifts Co0 content to 20.5 % (Table 2, entry 2). After reaction, the Co0 amount in Pt/Co2Al-700 was vastly increased (Table 2, entries 3 and 4), although the amount after ten cycles is smaller than after one run. This suggests that some CoOx species are reduced to Co0 during the APR process. Considering that Co2Al-700 is nearly inactive for the APR of methanol (Table 1, entry 3), Pt0 should be mainly responsible for the high APR activity (Figs. 3 and 9c), although Co0 species have a catalytic role, too (Table 1, entries 4 and 5). Fig. 9b shows that the impregnation of Pt on Co2Al-700 generates more oxygen vacancies (Oβ). In addition, the formation of more Oβ after the first reaction led to improved catalytic performance in the 2nd cycle (Fig. 3b and Table 2, entry 3). The increase of Oγ content with the reaction runs indicates the generation of large numbers of adsorbed OH groups during the reaction process. 3.4 Mechanism study by in situ DRIFTS and TPSR Generally, APR of methanol occurs via a tandem process consisting of sequential methanol dehydrogenation and WGS reaction: (1) CH3OH →CO + 2 H2 (2) H2O + CO → CO2 + H2 In situ DRIFTS for APR of methanol on Pt/Co2Al-700 at 30 ºC is shown in Fig. 10. Both methanol and water increase with their injection amounts (Fig. 10c). The band for methoxy species at 1109 cm−1 ( Table 3 and Fig. 10c) shows an evolution similar to that of methanol, suggesting that CH3OH is firstly dehydrogenated to methoxy species [24,25,76]. The bands at 2073 and 1960 cm−1, attributed to adsorbed CO (Table 3), show a volcanic relationship in intensity with the time on steam (Fig. 10d). It is consistent with the evolution of formaldehyde characterized by the band at 1716 cm−1, indicating that CO may be generated by formaldehyde dehydrogenation (Fig. 10d). Interestingly, the bands of bidentate formate species ([νs(OCO)] at 1363 cm−1 and [νas(OCO)] at 1590 cm−1] reach the highest intensity at the time (3 min) with the formation of the largest amount of CO (Fig. 10c and d) [77]. Formate species may be formed by two pathways, viz. WGS reaction and adsorbed formaldehyde oxidation [78,79]. The bands at 2982, 2918, 1481, 1406, and 1389 cm−1 are associated with polyoxymethylene (POM) [80]. These bands significantly increase in intensity from 7 min, indicative of the occurrence of formaldehyde polymerization. POM is difficult to convert on Pt/Co2Al-700 at 30 °C, which accounts for the decrease in CO amount. Fig. S14 shows that the POM signals can be observed even at the reaction temperature of 100 °C after purging with Ar. The decrease of CO2 with the descending CO supports that CO2 is produced from the WGS reaction. A similar evolution was observed for the APR of methanol at 220 ºC (Fig. S15), except that formaldehyde was not detected because it is quickly converted into CO at high temperatures. The generation of large amounts of CO and CO2 substantiates the high catalytic activity of Pt/Co2Al-700. The appearance of a band at 3740 cm−1 indicates the formation of surface OH groups. Compared to the APR process, methanol decomposition over Pt/Co2Al-700 gives a smaller amount of CO below 100 °C (Fig. S16a). The appearance of an intense band at 1102 cm−1 implies that dehydrogenation of methoxy species is difficult to occur in the absence of water (Fig. S16b). This suggests that water plays a critical role in the dehydrogenation of methoxy species to formaldehyde. To further prove the contribution of water to the conversion of methanol, it was introduced into the reaction cell after methanol decomposition at 220 °C. A comparison of the curve collected at 15 min with that at 1 min (the yellow top curve in Fig. 11) reveals a severe decrease in the intensity for the bands of methanol and methoxy species, confirming that the addition of water promotes the reaction of these species. Simultaneously, the bands of adsorbed CO at 2013 and 1923 cm−1 became negative, supporting that CO is converted into CO2 through the WGS reaction. The positive bands at 1375 cm−1 and 1589 cm−1 indicate the formation of formate species. Moreover, the intensity of CO2 centered at 2345 cm−1 presents a trend of increasing and then decreasing with time on steam. Therefore, adding water promotes not only the decomposition of methanol but also the WGS reaction. In situ DRIFTS for APR of methanol on Co2Al-700 reduced at 300 °C shows that methanol can be transformed to formate species (vibrations in the range of 1340–1589 cm−1 and at 1678 cm−1) (Fig. S17), but CO is not detected [81]. The detected small amounts of CO2 arise from the partial decomposition of formate species. This indicates that the APR of methanol is challenging without Pt NPs. The desorption behaviors of water, methanol, CO2, and CO over Co2Al-700 were investigated by TPD techniques ( Fig. 12a). The desorption temperature decreases in the order of H2O (115 ºC) > methanol (110 ºC) > CO2 (88 ºC), indicating that H2O is much more strongly adsorbed on the Co2Al-700 than methanol, and particularly CO2. The absence of a CO desorption peak in the CO-TPD profile confirms that CO was oxidized to CO2 on Co2Al-700 as CO2 signal was observed at 96 ºC (Fig. S18a). CO-TPD results on Pt/Co2Al-700 (Fig. S18b) show that CO can be adsorbed on Pt NPs, in agreement with the result of DRIFTS of CO adsorption (Fig. 6). Abundant oxygen vacancies on Co2Al-700 are beneficial to methanol adsorption, especially of water molecules. The oxygen vacancies have been proved to promote the dissociation of H2O to OH group, with the other activated H atom transferring to neighboring surface oxygen atoms [7]. Interestingly, a linear relationship was observed between H2 production rate and oxygen vacancy contents in Pt/CoxAl-y catalysts ( Fig. 13). This can be accounted for by the fact that H2O activation is the crucial step in the APR and WGS reactions [23,76]. Fig. 12b shows the temperature-programed surface reaction (TPSR) chromatogram for APR of methanol on Pt/Co2Al-700. The H2 and CO signals intensify with the consumption of methanol at ≥ 160 °C, indicative of the occurrence of APR. CO2 and HCOOH enhance as CO decreases from 205 °C, and their similar evolution profiles consolidate that CO2 is produced by the WGS reaction, which occurs via an associative mechanism, with formate as a crucial intermediate (Fig. 10 and Fig. S15) [25,82,83]. In situ DRIFTS of WGS also demonstrates the formation of formate species (Fig. S19). Based on the above results, a plausible mechanism is proposed for the APR of methanol on Pt/CoxAl-y. CH3OH is firstly dehydrogenated to methoxy species on oxygen vacancies. Then, it is sequentially dehydrogenated into formaldehyde and *CO species on Pt0, despite that Co0 sites can catalyze too. The *CO subsequently reacts with OH groups generated by the dissociation of H2O on oxygen vacancies to form formate intermediates that are decomposed into CO2 and H2. 4 Conclusions A series of Pt/CoxAl-y catalysts have been prepared by calcining CoAl-LDHs at high temperatures and further anchoring Pt NPs. Upon optimization of the Co/Al ratio and calcination temperature, this material showed high catalytic performance for the APR of methanol. H2 production rate of 3372 µmolH2·g−1 catalyst·min−1 (TOF = 4737 h−1) was achieved on Pt/Co2Al-700, along with CO selectivity of only 0.3 %. The catalytic performance decreased slightly over ten cycles. H2 production rate can be further elevated to 5680 µmolH2·g−1 catalyst·min−1 by raising the reduction temperature from 300 to 600 °C with a slight increase of CO selectivity to 0.69 %. This is due to a stronger interaction between Pt and CoxAl-y, which facilitates the reduction of Co ions. Methanol is first dehydrogenated to methoxy species and then to formaldehyde and CO on metallic Pt0 and Co0. CO will react with H2O by WGS reaction to produce CO2 and H2, with formate species as intermediates. A linear relationship exists between intrinsic reaction activity and oxygen vacancy content. Abundant oxygen vacancies on CoxAl-y support are conducive to the adsorption and activation of methanol and water. coredata.dc:description: A series of CoAl oxide-supported Pt catalysts (Pt/CoxAl, x = Co/Al ratio) was developed for aqueous-phase reforming of methanol to H2. CoxAl oxides were prepared by calcining layered double hydroxides at different temperatures. The catalytic performance of Pt/CoxAl highly depends on the Co/Al ratio and the calcination temperature. The most active Pt/Co2Al catalyst calcined at 700 °C showed an H2 production rate of 3372 µmolH2·g−1 catalyst·min−1 with low CO selectivity. The intense interaction between Pt and support and abundant oxygen vacancies results in high catalytic performance. Intensive characterization and mechanism study reveal that both Pt0 and metallic Co0 promote methanol decomposition. At the same time, H2O is activated on the support and reacts with CO to generate intermediate formate species that are further converted into CO2 and H2.
coredata.dc:title: Aqueous-phase reforming of methanol to hydrogen over CoAl oxide-supported Pt catalyst
